history.content: I'd say this is pretty doable. 16a is not a super difficult class if you did well in 70, and it generally has low/medium workload. Weaver's said he's reducing his 61c workload to match this semester, so it shouldn't be too bad either. 61b will probably be your most time consuming class, but if you've coded a lot in Java you'll have an advantage going in. Learning C is not difficult at all if you know java, and that's only the first few weeks of 61c anyways.

I'd say this is pretty doable. 16a is not a super difficult class if you did well in 70, and it generally has a medium workload. Weaver's said he's reducing his 61c workload to match this semester, so it shouldn't be too bad either. 61b will probably be your most time consuming class, but if you've coded a lot in Java you'll have an advantage going in. Learning C is not difficult at all if you know java, and that's only the first few weeks of 61c anyways.

children.subject: As someone taking B and C together right now: When you take 61B after A, you're beginning to remove the layers of abstraction in high level programming levels. You learn how the lists and dictionaries and sorting algorithms actually work; you realize something that looks as complicated as hash tables boils down to math and pointers. But it's kind of a tease, because you're thinking "Ok, so hash tables reduce to math and pointers. But can we go deeper? What actually is a pointer, or an int?" And 61C teaches you that, it teaches you that ints are just bits that the computer looks at a certain way, and pointers are just bits that the computer looks at another way and does some stuff with. 61B is the tip of the iceberg that is 'what actually is code,' and 61C is (an introductory look at) the rest of the iceberg.
61B & C together is quite synergistic, actually.

original OP here:

I really appreciate the advice and how thorough you were with it. I'm asking how feasible it is to take these classes and appreciate the material, not because I'm just trying to speed-run the CS department here (though there's nothing wrong with that either if that's what you want).
Original commenter: yes, I believe it is possible to get a good appreciation of the material assuming that you don't have anything else that takes a lot of time.

I think a lot of answers to questions like these miss the point. Is it possible to to take these three classes together and do well if you have a lot of relevant experience? Of course. That doesn't mean it's a good idea though. Studying CS at Berkeley is about so much more than the classes you take. Building relationships with piers is far more rewarding and will be far more useful to you in the real world. Joining a club and taking on leadership positions will help you grow. Doing research will be more useful to you if you want to pursue an academic career and will challenge you in a completely different way. Personal projects will let you focus on what you find most fun to develop and will make you a better software developer for industry. Having a job (in CS or not) will show you how to be a professional.

There's also a lot more to college than just preparing yourself for a career in CS. You should take classes in other departments (more than what LS/EECS require) to learn about different subjects and to see what else you have interests in. This is a unique time in your life socially as well. You'll never be around so many other like-minded people with similar interests that are the same age as you again. This is the the time of your life when you learn so much about yourself because of the unique experiences you can have. Don't waste this time.

I'm a senior and when I graduate next semester I will have taken literally every undergrad class in CS that interested me (which is most of them) and a grad class. I could have taken even more grad classes if I didn't flirt with two different double majors and waste time taking their useless prereqs. I never took a schedule this challenging and because of that I got to do pretty much all of things I mentioned above.

I'll step off my soapbox now and say that the obvious exceptions apply if you have to graduate early for personal/financial reasons or if you are a transfer student. I'm not just writing this for OP, but also for everyone else that looks at this thread and worries that they're underachieving if they "only" take 61b and 16b in their freshman spring.

history.content:
Hi!

Wanted to get some feedback on potentially taking 61C/61B/16A together. I've coded a lot in Java before, but have no experience in C. For reference, I've taken Math 53, CS 61A, and CS 70  and did well. How feasible is this / does anyone who has done this before have any advice?
history.subject: 61C/61B/16A Concurrently
